caption: Figure 1. MMDocIR comprises 313 lengthy documents across 10 different domains, along with 1,685 questions. For each question, page-level annotations are provided via selected screenshots. Red boundary boxes represent layout-level annotations.
description: Figure 1 illustrates the MMDocIR dataset, which consists of 313 lengthy documents spanning 10 diverse domains and 1,685 associated questions.  Each question is meticulously annotated at both the page and layout levels. Page-level annotations are indicated by selected screenshots, highlighting the relevant pages for each question.  Layout-level annotations further refine this by using red boundary boxes to pinpoint specific sections (paragraphs, figures, tables, etc.) within those pages that contain the answer.  This multi-level annotation enhances the dataset's utility for evaluating various granularities of document retrieval models.

caption: Figure 2. Area ratio of different modalities (1) in overall and (2) by domains in MMLongBench-Doc benchmark (Ma et al., 2024b). Note that the white spaces, headers, and footers are removed from the area counting.
description: This figure displays the proportions of different content modalities (text, images, tables) within documents from the MMLongBench-Doc benchmark.  It shows the overall distribution across all document types and then breaks it down further to illustrate the modality ratios specific to seven different document categories (Overall, Research Report, Administration & Industry, Tutorial & Workshop, Academic Paper, Brochure, Financial Report, Guidebook). Note that the calculation excludes whitespace, headers, and footers.

caption: (a) Avg word length
description: This figure is a combined bar chart and histogram showing the average word length and the distribution of word lengths for OCR text and VLM text extracted from tables and images in the MMDocIR dataset.  The bar chart displays the average word length for OCR text and VLM text in tables and images separately. The histogram visually represents the distribution of word lengths for each category, showing the frequency of different word lengths. This comparison helps illustrate the differences in text characteristics between OCR-generated text and text generated by a Vision Language Model (VLM), highlighting the richer and more descriptive nature of VLM-generated text.
section: 6.5 Analysis of OCR and VLM Text

caption: (b) Distribution density of word length
description: The figure shows the distribution density of word lengths for OCR and VLM text extracted from tables and image captions within the MMDocIR dataset.  It provides a visual comparison of the word length distributions between the two methods, revealing differences in their ability to capture the complexity of visual information present in documents.
section: Analysis of OCR and VLM Text
